Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: New Ligand Shells for Small Quantum Dots

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit. When proteins are tagged with reporter labels to trace the locations and movements of the proteins on or within cells, the physical size of the label can be quite significant. This is especially true for the popular class of labels called quantum dots (qdots), which are inorganic crystals with intense fluorescence. The core of a qdot is fairly small, 2-4 nm, but is completely insoluble. To make them soluble in water-based buffers requires a hydrophobic-hydrophilic ligand shell. Commercially-available qdots are typically 21 nm in diameter. The research will make a ligand-shield that is only about 2 nm thick. The shield will have a sulfur atom that binds the qdot-core very tightly. This sulfur will either be a thiol, a thioether, or a thioketone. This sulfur will also have a polyethylene glycol, making the entity water soluble. It may have a negative or positive charge to reduce non-specific sticking. Finally, it will have a bioreactive entity for coupling.

Broader Impacts. Quantum dots have tremendous potential as incredibly bright fluorophores for labeling proteins. However, their large size has limited their usefulness as biological tracers. The research presented here intends to overcome this limitation by providing to the research community methods to make a new class of water-soluble quantum dots that are significantly smaller than those currently commercially available. The research provides excellent training for synthetic chemists and graduate students who are interested in basic optics, microscopy, and spectroscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have been involved in some new chemistry and some new microscopy looking at neural cells (also called neurons). Your brain has 80-100 billion neurons, with each one connected to an average of 1000 other neurons. (Yes, your brain is highly parallel, in comparison to the basically serial architecture of man-made computers.)

These connections are through synapses, because Nerve 1 doesn't actually touch Nerve 2, but must go through a thin space, 20-40 nanometers, in size. On one end are “post-synaptic” receptors, called AMPA- and NMDA- receptors. These are receptors for the amino acid glutamate. A nerve impulse in Nerve 1 causes glutamate to be released at the pre-synapse, which rapidly diffuses across the synapse and interacts with the receptors, causing another nerve impulse in Nerve 2. 

Your ability to learn and remember has to do with more, or less, AMPA receptors at the post-synapses, which are partially controlled by NMDA receptors. Common neurodegenerative diseases occur when this circuitry has gone wrong. Alzheimer’s disease, for example, is the 6th leading cause of death in the United States; it is also the most common cause of dementia, which affects over 44 million people worldwide.

Our goal is to examine a single synapse. In this way, the synapse does not need to be coordinated with any other synapse, and the rate at which the receptors move can be directly determined. Fluorescence has the sensitivity for studying things at the single-molecule level. Because of the size of the synapse, and the extended time of measurement, which can last for a half-hour or more, regular (organic-based) fluorophores are of limited use here. Quantum dots, a semiconducting fluorophore, are extremely bright and photostable. They have been used with some success before. However, they are about 20 nm in diameter, which we have shown is too big to get in the small synapse. (We call them big quantum dots, or bQDs.)

The idea behind this project was to make “small” quantum dots (sQDs). We made some that are about one-half the size of bQDs, or about 10 nm across. What we showed is that the bQDs have only a 15% chance of getting into a synapse, while the sQDs had an 85-95% chance. (Published in Cai, et al., 2014.)  In addition, we made a linker that connected the sQD to the receptor, which was unusually small. The new sQDs, together with single-molecule microscopy, have the potential for transforming the field of experimental neuroscience. Already, we have shown that AMPA-receptors diffuse around little corrals, which are called nanodomains, and that our sQDs tend not to cross-link the receptors, which is a problem with bQDs.
